text: [Music]
the people who I really am interested in
in American history are the the people
at the edge the dissenters the critics
the radicals the people like Frederick
Douglas who pressured lincol Wendell
Phillips the people like Susan B Anthony
the people like Eugene Debs later on in
the early 20th century or web Debo uh
the people who stood outside the um the
accepted boundaries of political
dialogue and tried to introduce new
ideas and new demands you know they
didn't succeed at the moment that they
were that they were operating but
without the abolitionists you would not
have had the Abolitionist slavery
without the populists and the Socialists
you would not have had an era where the
government took responsibility for the
econom without the dues and the Paul
roons and the Kings and others you would
not have had a great civil rights
Revolution so to me the driving force of
change in this country change for the
good has been those people who've been
at the margins and I you know my view of
American History is we've got to reenter
it a little bit and not just give us the
history of the presidents and the
bankers and the captains of industry but
let's look at the people at the margins
and how they affect the the the
trajectory of American
history
it's hard to generalize about people
over two centuries or more uh I've
written a lot about such people starting
with Tom Payne in the American
Revolution and running down to others
but I think um uh it is it's they must
have some deep source of belief that
keeps them going now for many it's a
religious belief you know religion has
inspired a great deal of social
radicalism in American history for
others it's a belief in a principle of
equality or Justice uh it's what the uh
historian EP Thompson the Great British
historian once wrote about as a notion
of right that doesn't mean right-wing it
means a notion of just what is just what
is moral what is right and if you
believe deeply in that that will enable
you to persevere and to try to change
the political discourse I mean that's
really what I think these radicals are
doing you know we don't have despite the
fact that bill SS has been in the disc
campaign we don't have much of a
tradition in America of violent
radicalism most of the people I
mentioned were completely nonviolent
people um their mode of operation was uh
was to try to change people's minds and
the first thing you have to do is to
change the boundaries of what is
acceptable to force issues into the
public debate when the Abolitionist
started you could not talk about slavery
there was a kind of conspiracy of
Silence about slavery forcing the issue
onto the political agenda is part of
what it is to be a Critic and I think at
many points in our history that has
happened and uh you know I hope today
and in the future we will continue to
have such people who Force the
uncomfortable issue into political
debate and thereby make it necessary for
politicians to deal with it in some
way
